editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE CRITIC OR A Tragedy Rehearsed A Dramatic Piece in three ACTS as it is performed at the THEATRE ROYAL in DRURY LANE

BY Richard Brinsley Sheridan Esqr
LONDON. Printed for T. Becket, Adelphi, Strand, MDCCLXXXI.

div.head: TO Mrs. GREVILLE.
div.p:
IN requeſting your permiſſion to addreſs the following pages to you, which as they aim themſelves to be critical, require every protection and allowance that approving taſte or friendly prejudice can give them, I yet ventured to mention no other motive than the gratification of private friendſhip and eſteem. Had I ſuggeſted a hope that your implied approbation would give a ſanction to their defects, your particular reſerve, and diſlike to the reputation of critical taſte, as well as of poetical talent, would have made you refuſe the protection of your name to ſuch a purpoſe. However, I am not ſo ungrateful as now to attempt to combat this diſpoſition in you. I ſhall not here preſume to argue that the preſent ſtate of poetry claims and expects every aſſiſtance that taſte and example can afford it: nor endeavour to prove that a faſtidious concealment of the moſt elegant productions of judgment and fancy is an ill return for the poſſeſſion of thoſe
endowments.—Continue to deceive yourſelf in the idea that you are known only to be eminently admired and regarded for the valuable qualities that attach private friendſhips, and the graceful talents that adorn converſation. Enough of what you have written, has ſtolen into full public notice to anſwer my purpoſe; and you will, perhaps, be the only perſon, converſant in elegant literature, who ſhall read this addreſs and not perceive that by publiſhing your particular approbation of the following drama, I have a more intereſted object than to boaſt the true reſpect and regard with which
div.closer: I have the honour to be, MADAM, Your very ſincere, And obedient humble ſervant, R. B. SHERIDAN.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: THE Siſter Muſes, whom theſe realms obey,
Who o'er the Drama hold divided ſway,
Sometimes, by evil counſellors, 'tis ſaid
Like earth-born potentates have been miſled:
In thoſe gay days of wickedneſs and wit,
When Villiers criticiz'd what Dryden writ,
The Tragick Queen, to pleaſe a taſteleſs crow'd,
Had learn'd to bellow, rant, and roar ſo loud,
That frighten'd Nature, her beſt friend before,
The bluſt'ring beldam's company forſwore.
Her comic Siſter, who had wit 'tis true,
With all her merits, had her failings too;
And would ſometimes in mirthful moments uſe
A ſtyle too flippant for a well-bred Muſe.
Then female modeſty abaſh'd began
To ſeek the friendly refuge of the fan,
Awhile behind that ſlight entrenchment ſtood,
'Till driv'n from thence, ſhe left the ſtage for good.
In our more pious, and far chaſter times!
Theſe ſure no longer are the Muſe's crimes!
But ſome complain that, former faults to ſhun,
The reformation to extremes has run.
The frantick hero's wild delirium paſt,
Now inſipidity ſucceeds bombaſt;
So ſlow Melpomene's cold numbers creep,
Here dullneſs ſeems her drowſy court to keep,
And we, are ſcarce awake, whilſt you are faſt aſleep.
Thalia, once ſo ill behav'd and rude,
Reform'd; is now become an arrant prude,
Retailing nightly to the yawning pit,
The pureſt morals, undefil'd by wit!
Our Author offers in theſe motley ſcenes,
A ſlight remonſtrance to the Drama's queens,
Nor let the goddeſſes be over nice;
Free ſpoken ſubjects give the beſt advice.
Although not quite a novice in his trade,
His cauſe to night requires no common aid.
To this, a friendly, juſt, and pow'rful court,
I come Ambaſſador to beg ſupport.
Can he undaunted, brave the critick's rage?
In civil broils, with brother bards engage?
Hold forth their errors to the publick eye,
Nay more, e'en News-papers themſelves defy?
Say, muſt his ſingle arm encounter all?
By numbers vanquiſh'd, e'en the brave may fall;
And though no leader ſhould ſucceſs diſtruſt,
Whoſe troops are willing, and whoſe cauſe is juſt;
To bid ſuch hoſts of angry foes defiance,
His chief dependance muſt be, YOUR ALLIANCE.

list.item:
AND
Puff Mr. KING.
Mrs. Dangle Mrs. HOPKINS.
Italian Girls Miſs FIELD, and the Miſs ABRAMS.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Mr. and Mrs. DANGLE at Breakfaſt, and reading Newſpapers.

sp.speaker: DANGLE (reading.)]
sp.p: BRUTUS to LORD NORTH.—Letter the ſecond, on the STATE OF THE ARMY.—Pſhaw! To the firſt L—daſh D of the A—daſh Y.—Genuine Extract of a Letter from ST. KITT's.—COXHEATH INTELLIGENCE.—It is now confidently aſſerted that SIR CHARLES HARDY.—Pſhaw!—Nothing but about the fleet, and the nation!—and I hate all politics but theatrical politics.—Where's the MORNING CHRONICLE?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Yes, that's your gazette.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: So, here we have it.—

"Theatrical intelligence extraordinary,"—We hear there is a new tragedy in rehearſal at Drury-Lane Theatre, call'd the SPANISH ARMADA, ſaid to be written by Mr. PUFF, a gentleman well known in the theatrical world; if we may allow ourſelves to give credit to the report of the performers, who, truth to ſay, are in general but indifferent judges, this piece abounds with the moſt ſtriking and received beauties of modern compoſition—So! I am very glad my friend PUFF's tragedy is in ſuch forwardneſs.—Mrs. Dangle, my dear, you will be very glad to hear that PUFF's tragedy—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Dangle, why will you plague me about ſuch nonſenſe?—Now the plays are begun I ſhall have no peace.—Isn't it ſufficient to make yourſelf ridiculous by your paſſion for the theatre, without continually teazing me to join you? Why can't you ride your hobby-horſe without deſiring to place me on a pillion behind you, Mr. Dangle?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Nay, my dear, I was only going to read—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: No, no; you never will read any thing that's worth liſtening to:—you hate to hear about your country; there are letters every day with Roman ſignatures, demonſtrating the certainty of an invaſion, and proving that the nation is utterly undone—But you never will read any thing to entertain one.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: What has a woman to do with politics, Mrs. Dangle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: And what have you to do with the theatre, Mr. Dangle? Why ſhould you affect the character of a Critic? I have no patience with you! —haven't you made yourſelf the jeſt of all your acquaintance by your interference in matters where you have no buſineſs? Are not you call'd a theatrical Quidnunc, and a mock Maecenas to ſecond-hand authors?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
True; my power with the Managers is pretty notorious; but is it no credit to have applications from all quarters for my intereſt?—From lords to recommend fidlers, from ladies to get
boxes, from authors to get anſwers, and from actors to get engagements.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Yes, truly; you have contrived to get a ſhare in all the plague and trouble of theatrical property, without the profit, or even the credit of the abuſe that attends it.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: I am ſure, Mrs. Dangle, you are no loſer by it, however; you have all the advantages of it: —mightn't you, laſt winter, have had the reading of the new Pantomime a fortnight previous to its performance? And doesn't Mr. Foſbrook let you take places for a play before it is advertis'd, and ſet you down for a Box for every new piece through the ſeaſon? And didn't my friend, Mr. Smatter, dedicate his laſt Farce to you at my particular requeſt, Mrs. Dangle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p:
Yes; but wasn't the Farce damn'd, Mr. Dangle? And to be ſure it is extremely pleaſant to have one's houſe made the motley rendezvous of all the lackeys of literature!—The very high change of trading authors and jobbing critics!—Yes, my drawing-room is an abſolute regiſter-office for candidate actors, and poets without character;—then to be continually alarmed with Miſſes and Ma'ams piping hiſteric changes on
JULIETS and DORINDAS, POLLYS and OPHELIAS; and the very furniture trembling at the probationary ſtarts and unprovok'd rants of would-be RICHARDS and HAMLETS!—And what is worſe than all, now that the Manager has monopoliz'd the Opera-Houſe, haven't we the Signors and Signioras calling here, ſliding their ſmooth ſemibreves, and gargling glib diviſions in their outlandiſh throats—with foreign emiſſaries and French ſpies, for ought I know, diſguiſed like fidlers and figure dancers!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Mercy! Mrs. Dangle!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: And to employ yourſelf ſo idly at ſuch an alarming criſis as this too—when, if you had the leaſt ſpirit, you would have been at the head of one of the Weſtminſter aſſociations—or trailing a volunteer pike in the Artillery Ground!—But you—o'my conſcience, I believe if the French were landed to-morrow, your firſt enquiry would be, whether they had brought a theatrical troop with them.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
Mrs. Dangle, it does not ſignify—I ſay the ſtage is "the Mirror of Nature," and the actors are "the Abſtract, and brief Chronicles of the Time:"—and pray what can a man of ſenſe
ſtudy better?—Beſides, you will not eaſily perſuade me that there is no credit or importance in being at the head of a band of critics, who take upon them to decide for the whole town, whoſe opinion and patronage all writers ſolicit, and whoſe recommendation no manager dares refuſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Ridiculous!—Both managers and authors of the leaſt merit, laugh at your pretenſions.—The PUBLIC is their CRITIC—without whoſe fair approbation they know no play can reſt on the ſtage, and with whoſe applauſe they welcome ſuch attacks as yours, and laugh at the malice of them, where they can't at the wit.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Very well, Madam—very well.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. Sneer, Sir, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: O, ſhew Mr. Sneer up.
Plague on't, now we muſt appear loving and affectionate, or Sneer will hitch us into a ſtory.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: With all my heart; you can't be more ridiculous than you are.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Your are enough to provoke—

sp.speaker: Enter Mr. SNEER.
sp.p: —Hah! my dear Sneer, I am vaſtly glad to ſee you. My dear, here's Mr. Sneer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Good morning to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Mrs. Dangle and I have been diverting ourſelves with the papers.—Pray, Sneer, won't you go to Drury-lane theatre the firſt night of Puff's tragedy?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Yes; but I ſuppoſe one ſhan't be able to get in, for on the firſt night of a new piece they always fill the houſe with orders to ſupport it. But here, Dangle, I have brought you two pieces, one of which you muſt exert yourſelf to make the Managers accept, I can tell you that, for 'tis written by a perſon of conſequence.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: So! now my plagues are beginning!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p:
Aye, I am glad of it, for now you'll be happy. Why, my dear Dangle, it is a pleaſure
to ſee how you enjoy your volunteer fatigue, and your ſolicited ſolicitations.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: It's a great trouble—yet, egad, its pleaſant too.—Why, ſometimes of a morning, I have a dozen people call on me at breakfaſt time, whoſe faces I never ſaw before, nor ever deſire to ſee again.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That muſt be very pleaſant indeed!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: And not a week but I receive fifty letters, and not a line in them about any buſineſs of my own.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: An amuſing correſpondence!

sp.speaker: DANGLE (reading.)
sp.p: "Burſts into tears, and exit." What, is this a tragedy?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No, that's a genteel comedy, not a tranſlation—only taken from the French; it is written in a ſtile which they have lately tried to run down; the true ſentimental, and nothing ridiculous in it from the beginning to the end.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Well, if they had kept to that, I ſhould not have been ſuch an enemy to the ſtage, there was ſome edification to be got from thoſe pieces, Mr. Sneer!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I am quite of your opinion, Mrs. Dangle; the theatre, in proper hands, might certainly be made the ſchool of morality; but now, I am ſorry to ſay it, people ſeem to go there principally for their entertainment!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: It would have been more to the credit of the Managers to have kept it in the other line.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Madam, and hereafter perhaps to have had it recorded, that in the midſt of a luxurious and diſſipated age, they preſerv'd two houſes in the capital, where the converſation was always moral at leaſt, if not entertaining!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Now, egad, I think the worſt alteration is in the nicety of the audience.—No double entendre, no ſmart inuendo admitted; even Vanburgh and Congreve oblig'd to undergo a bungling reformation!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Yes, and our prudery in this reſpect is juſt on a par with the artificial baſhfulneſs of a courtezan, who encreaſes the bluſh upon her cheek in an exact proportion to the diminution of her modeſty.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Sneer can't even give the Public a good word!—But what have we here?—This ſeems a very odd—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: O, that's a comedy, on a very new plan; replete with wit and mirth, yet of a moſt ſerious moral! You ſee it is call'd "THE REFORMED HOUSEBREAKER;" where, by the mere force of humour, HOUSEBREAKING is put into ſo ridiculous a light, that if the piece has its proper run, I have no doubt but that bolts and bars will be entirely uſeleſs by the end of the ſeaſon.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad, this is new indeed!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p:
Yes; it is written by a particular friend of mine, who has diſcovered that the follies and foibles of ſociety, are ſubjects unworthy the notice of the Comic Muſe, who ſhould be taught to ſtoop only at the greater vices and blacker crimes of humanity—gibbeting capital offences in five acts, and pillorying petty larcenies in two.—In ſhort,
his idea is to dramatize the penal laws, and make the Stage a court of eaſe to the Old Bailey.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: It is truly moral.

sp.speaker: Enter SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir Fretful Plagiary, Sir.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Beg him to walk up.— [Exit Servant.] Now, Mrs. Dangle, Sir Fretful Plagiary is an author to your own taſte.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: I confeſs he is a favourite of mine, becauſe every body elſe abuſes him.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: —Very much to the credit of your charity, Madam, if not of your judgment.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But, egad, he allows no merit to any author but himſelf, that's the truth on't—tho' he's my friend.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p:
Never.—He is as envious as an old maid verging on the deſperation of ſix-and-thirty: and then the inſiduous humility with which he ſeduces you to give a free opinion on any of his
works, can be exceeded only by the petulant arrogance with which he is ſure to reject your obſervations.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Very true, egad—tho' he's my friend.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Then his affected contempt of all newſpaper ſtrictures; tho', at the ſame time, he is the ſoreſt man alive, and ſhrinks like ſcorch'd parchment from the fiery ordeal of true criticiſm: yet is he ſo covetous of popularity, that he had rather be abuſed than not mentioned at all.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: There's no denying it—tho' he is my friend.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: You have read the tragedy he has juſt finiſhed, haven't you?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: O yes; he ſent it to me yeſterday.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Well, and you think it execrable, don't you?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
Why between ourſelves, egad I muſt own—tho' he's my friend—that it is one of the moſt
—He's here [Aſide]—finiſhed and moſt admirable perform—
[Sir Fretful without.] Mr. Sneer with him, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Enter Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Ah, my dear friend!—Egad, we were juſt ſpeaking of your Tragedy.—Admirable, Sir Fretful, admirable!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: You never did any thing beyond it, Sir Fretful —never in your life.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: You make me extremely happy;—for without a compliment, my dear Sneer, there isn't a man in the world whoſe judgment I value as I do yours.—And Mr. Dangle's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: They are only laughing at you, Sir Fretful; for it was but juſt now that—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Mrs. Dangle!—Ah, Sir Fretful, you know Mrs. Dangle.—My friend Sneer was rallying juſt now—He knows how ſhe admires you, and—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: O Lord—I am ſure Mr. Sneer has more taſte and ſincerity than to—A damn'd double-faced fellow!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Yes, yes,—Sneer will jeſt—but a better humour'd—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: O, I know—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: He has a ready turn for ridicule—his wit coſts him nothing.—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: No, egad—or I ſhould wonder how he came by it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Becauſe his jeſt is always at the expence of his friend.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But, Sir Fretful, have you ſent your play to the managers yet?—or can I be of any ſervice to you?

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: No, No, I thank you; I believe the piece had ſufficient recommendation with it.—I thank you tho'.—I ſent it to the manager of COVENTGARDEN THEATRE this morning.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I ſhould have thought now, that it might have been caſt (as the actors call it) better at DRURY-LANE

sp.speaker: Sir. FRETFUL.
sp.p: O lud! no—never ſend a play there while I live—harkee! [Whiſpers Sneer.]

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Writes himſelf!—I know he does—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: I ſay nothing—I take away from no man's merit—am hurt at no man's good fortune—I ſay nothing.—But this I will ſay—through all my knowledge of life, I have obſerv'd—that there is not a paſſion ſo ſtrongly rooted in the human heart as envy!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I believe you have reaſon for what you ſay, indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Beſides—I can tell you it is not always ſo ſafe to leave a play in the hands of thoſe who write themſelves.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What, they may ſteal from them, hey, my dear Plagiary?

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Steal!—to beſure they may; and, egad, ſerve your beſt thoughts as gypſies do ſtolen children, disfigure them to make 'em paſs for their own.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But your preſent work is a ſacrifice to Melpomene, and HE, you know, never—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: That's no ſecurity.—A dext'rous plagiariſt may do any thing.—Why, Sir, for ought I know, he might take out ſome of the beſt things in my tragedy, and put them into his own comedy.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That might be done, I dare be ſworn.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: And then, if ſuch a perſon gives you the leaſt hint or aſſiſtance, he is deviliſh apt to take the merit of the whole.—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: If it ſucceeds.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Aye—but with regard to this piece, I think I can hit that gentleman, for I can ſafely ſwear he never read it.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I'll tell you how you may hurt him more—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: How?—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Swear he wrote it.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Plague on't now, Sneer, I ſhall take it ill.—I believe you want to take away my character as an author!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Then I am ſure you ought to be very much oblig'd to me.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Hey!—Sir!—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: O you know, he never means what he ſays.

sp.speaker: Sir FRTEFUL.
sp.p: Sincerely then—you do like the piece?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Wonderfully!

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: But come now, there muſt be ſomething that you think might be mended, hey?—Mr. Dangle, has nothing ſtruck you?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Why faith, it is but an ungracious thing for the moſt part to—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p:
—With moſt authors it is juſt ſo indeed; they are in general ſtrangely tenacious!—But, for
my part, I am never ſo well pleaſed as when a judicious critic points out any defect to me; for what is the purpoſe of ſhewing a work to a friend, if you don't mean to profit by his opinion?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Very true.—Why then, tho' I ſeriouſly admire the piece upon the whole, yet there is one ſmall objection; which, if you'll give me leave, I'll mention.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: SIR, you can't oblige me more.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I think it wants incident.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Good God!—you ſurprize me!—wants incident!—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Yes; I own I think the incidents are too few.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Good God!—Believe me, Mr. Sneer, there is no perſon for whoſe judgment I have a more implicit deference.—But I proteſt to you, Mr. Sneer, I am only apprehenſive that the incidents are too crowded.—My dear Dangle, how does it ſtrike you?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
Really I can't agree with my friend Sneer.—I
think the plot quite ſufficient; and the four firſt acts by many degrees the beſt I ever read or ſaw in my life. If I might venture to ſuggeſt any thing, it is that the intereſt rather falls off in the fifth.—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —Riſes; I believe you mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: No; I don't upon my word.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you do upon my ſoul—it certainly don't fall off, I aſſure you—No, no, it don't fall off.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Dangle, didn't you ſay it ſtruck you in the ſame light?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not—I did not ſee a fault in any part of the play from the beginning to the end.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul the women are the beſt judges after all!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Or if I made any objection, I am ſure it was to nothing in the piece; but that I was afraid it was, on the whole, a little too long.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p:
Pray, Madam, do you ſpeak as to duration of
time; or do you mean that the ſtory is tediouſly ſpun out?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: O Lud! no.—I ſpeak only with reference to the uſual length of acting plays.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Then I am very happy—very happy indeed,—becauſe the play is a ſhort play, a remarkably ſhort play:—I ſhould not venture to differ with a lady on a point of taſte; but, on theſe occaſions, the watch, you know, is the critic.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Then, I ſuppoſe, it muſt have been Mr. Dangle's drawling manner of reading it to me.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: O, if Mr. Dangle read it! that's quite another affair!—But I aſſure you, Mrs. Dangle, the firſt evening you can ſpare me three hours and an half, I'll undertake to read you the whole from beginning to end, with the Prologue and Epilogue, and allow time for the muſic between the acts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: I hope to ſee it on the ſtage next.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
Well, Sir Fretful, I wiſh you may be able to
get rid as eaſily of the news-paper criticiſms as you do of ours.—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: The NEWS-PAPERS!—Sir, they are the moſt villainous—licentious—abominable—infernal—Not that I ever read them—No—I make it a rule never to look into a news-paper.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: You are quite right—for it certainly muſt hurt an author of delicate feelings to ſee the liberties they take

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: No!—quite the contrary;—their abuſe is, in fact, the beſt panegyric—I like it of all things.—An author's reputation is only in danger from their ſupport.

sp.speaker: Mr. SNEER.
sp.p: Why that's true—and that attack now on you the other day—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —What? where?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Aye, you mean in a paper of Thurſday; it was compleatly ill-natur'd to be ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: O, ſo much the better.—Ha! ha! ha!—I wou'dn't have it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Certainly it is only to be laugh'd at; for—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —You don't happen to recollect what the fellow ſaid, do you?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Pray, Dangle—Sir Fretful ſeems a little anxious—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —O lud, no!—anxious,—not I,—not the leaſt. —I—But one may as well hear you know.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Sneer, do you recollect?—Make out ſomething.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I will, [to Dangle.]—Yes, yes, I remember perfectly.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Well, and pray now—Not that it ſignifies—what might the gentleman ſay?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Why, he roundly aſſerts that you have not the ſlighteſt invention, or original genius whatever; tho' you are the greateſt traducer of all other authors living.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—very good!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That as to COMEDY, you have not one idea of your own, he believes, even in your common place-book—where ſtray jokes, and pilfered witticiſms are kept with as much method as the ledger of the LOST-and-STOLEN-OFFICE.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —Ha! ha! ha!—very pleaſant!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Nay, that you are ſo unlucky as not to have the ſkill even to ſteal with taſte.—But that you gleen from the refuſe of obſcure volumes, where more judicious plagiariſts have been before you; ſo that the body of your work is a compoſition of dregs and ſediments—like a bad tavern's worſt wine.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: In your more ſerious efforts, he ſays, your bombaſt would be leſs intolerable, if the thoughts were ever ſuited to the expreſſion; but the homelineſs of the ſentiment ſtares thro' the fantaſtic encumbrance of it's fine language, like a clown in one of the new uniforms!

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That your occaſional tropes and flowers ſuit the general coarſeneſs of your ſtile, as tambour ſprigs would a ground of linſey-wolfey; while your imitations of Shakeſpeare reſemble the mimicry of Falſtaff's Page, and are about as near the ſtandard of the original.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Ha!—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: —In ſhort, that even the fineſt paſſages you ſteal are of no ſervice to you; for the poverty of your own language prevents their aſſimilating; ſo that they lie on the ſurface like lumps of marl on a barren moor, encumbering what it is not in their power to fertilize!—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —Now another perſon would be vex'd at this.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Oh! but I wou'dn't have told you, only to divert you.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: I know it—I am diverted,—Ha! ha! ha!—not the leaſt invention!—Ha! ha! ha! very good!—very good!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Yes—no genius! Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: A ſevere rogue! Ha! ha! ha! But you are quite right, Sir Fretful, never to read ſuch nonſenſe.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: To be ſure—for if there is any thing to one's praiſe, it is a fooliſh vanity to be gratified at it, and if it is abuſe,—why one is always ſure to hear of it from one damn'd good natur'd friend or another!

sp.speaker: Enter SERVANT.
sp.p: Sir, there is an Italian gentleman, with a French Interpreter, and three young ladies, and a dozen muſicians, who ſay they are ſent by LADY RONDEAU and MRS. FUGE.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Gadſo! they come by appointment. Dear Mrs. Dangle do let them know I'll ſee them directly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: You know, Mr. Dangle, I ſhan't underſtand a word they ſay.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But you hear there's an interpreter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Well, I'll try to endure their complaiſance till you come.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: And Mr. PUFF, Sir, has ſent word that the laſt rehearſal is to be this morning, and that he'll call on you preſently.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's true—I ſhall certainly be at home. [Exit Servant.] Now, Sir Fretful, if you have a mind to have juſtice done you in the way of anſwer—Egad, Mr. PUFF's your man.

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Sir, why ſhould I wiſh to have it anſwered, when I tell you I am pleaſed at it?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: True, I had forgot that.—But I hope you are not fretted at what Mr. Sneer—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: —Zounds! no, Mr. Dangle, don't I tell you theſe things never fret me in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Nay, I only thought—

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p:
—And let me tell you, Mr. Dangle, 'tis
damn'd affronting in you to ſuppoſe that I am hurt, when I tell you I am not.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But why ſo warm, Sir Fretful?

sp.speaker: Sir FRETFUL.
sp.p: Gadſlife! Mr. Sneer, you are as abſurd as Dangle; how often muſt I repeat it to you, that nothing can vex me but your ſuppoſing it poſſible for me to mind the damn'd nonſenſe you have been repeating to me!—and let me tell you, if you continue to believe this, you muſt mean to inſult me, gentlemen—and then your diſreſpect will affect me no more than the newspaper criticiſms—and I ſhall treat it—with exactly the ſame calm indifference and philoſophic contempt—and ſo your ſervant.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Poor Sir Fretful! Now will he go and vent his philoſophy in anonymous abuſe of all modern critics and authors—But, Dangle, you muſt get you friend PUFF to take me to the rehearſal of his tragedy.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for't, he'll thank you for deſiring it. But come and help me to judge of this muſical family; they are recommended by people of conſequence, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: I am at your diſpoſal the whole morning—but I thought you had been a decided critic in muſick, as well as in literature?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: So I am—but I have a bad ear.—Efaith, Sneer, tho', I am afraid we were a little too ſevere on Sir Fretful—tho' he is my friend.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Why, 'tis certain, that unneceſſarily to mortify the vanity of any writer, is a cruelty which mere dulneſs never can deſerve; but where a baſe and perſonal malignity uſurps the place of literary emulation, the aggreſſor deſerves neither quarter nor pity.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's ture egad!—tho' he's my friend!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Drawing Room, Harpſichord, &c. Italian Family, French Interpreter, Mrs. Dangle and Servants diſcovered.

sp.speaker: INTERPRETER.
sp.p: Je dis madame, ja'i l'honneur to introduce & de vous demander votre protection pour le Signor PASTICCIO RETORNELLO & pour ſa charmante famille.

sp.speaker: Signor PASTICCIO.
sp.p: Ah! Voſignoria noi vi preghiamo di favori tevi colla voſtra protezione.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. DAUGHTER.
sp.p: Voſignoria fatevi queſti grazzie.

sp.speaker: 2nd DAUGHTER.
sp.p: Si Signora.

sp.speaker: INTERPRETER.
sp.p: Madame—me interpret.—C'eſt à dire—in Engliſh—quils vous prient de leur faire l'honneur—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: —I ſay again, gentlemen, I don't underſtand a word you ſay.

sp.speaker: Signor PASTICCIO.
sp.p: Queſto Signore ſpiegheró.

sp.speaker: INTERPRETER.
sp.p: Oui—me interpret.—nous avons les lettres de recommendation pour Monſieur Dangle de—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: —Upon my word, Sir, I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Signor PASTICCIO.
sp.p: La CONTESSA RONDEAU e noſtra padrona.

sp.speaker: 3d DAUGHTER.
sp.p: Si, padre, & mi LADI FUGE.

sp.speaker: INTERPRETER.
sp.p: O!—me interpret.—Madame, ils diſent—in Engliſh—Qu'ils ont l'honneur d'etre proteges de ces Demes.—You underſtand?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: No, Sir,—no underſtand!

sp.speaker: All ITALIANS.
sp.p: A! Signor Dangle!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DANGLE.
sp.p: Mr. Dangle, here are two very civil gentlemen trying to make themſelves underſtood, and I don't know which is the interpreter.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Ebien!

sp.speaker: INTERPRETER.
sp.p: Monſieur Dangle—le grand bruit de vos talents pour la critique & de votre intereſt avec Meſſieurs les Directeurs a tous les Theatres.

sp.speaker: Signor PASTICCIO.
sp.p: Voſignoria ſiete ſi famoſo par la voſtra conoſcenſa e voſtra intereſſa colla le Direttore da—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad I think the Interpreter is the hardeſt to be underſtood of the two!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Why I thought, Dangle, you had been an admirable linguiſt!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: So I am, if they would not talk ſo damn'd faſt.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Well I'll explain that—the leſs time we loſe in hearing them the better,—for that I ſuppoſe is what they are brought here for.
[Sneer ſpeaks to Sig. Paſt. —They ſing trios, &c. Dangle beating out of time. Servant enters and whiſpers Dangle.]

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Shew him up. [Exit Servant.]
Bravo! admirable! braviſſimo! admirabliſſimo! —Ah! Sneer! where will you find ſuch as theſe voices in England?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Not eaſily.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p:
But PUFF is coming.—Signor and little Signora's—obligatiſſimo!—Spoſa Signora Danglena
—Mrs. Dangle, ſhall I beg you to offer them ſome refreſhments, and take their addreſs in the next room.
sp.stage: [Exit Mrs. Dangle with the Italians and Interpreter ceremoniouſly.]

sp.speaker: Re-enter SERVANT.
sp.p: Mr. PUFF, Sir!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: My dear PUFF!

sp.speaker: Enter PUFF.
sp.p: My dear Dangle, how is it with you?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Mr. Sneer, give me leave to introduce Mr. PUFF to you.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Mr. Sneer is this? Sir, he is a gentleman whom I have long panted for the honour of knowing—a gentleman whoſe critical talents and tranſcendant judgment—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: —Dear Sir—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Nay, don't be modeſt, Sneer, my friend PUFF only talks to you in the ſtile of his profeſſion.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: His profeſſion!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I make no ſecret of the trade I follow—among friends and brother authors, Dangle knows I love to be frank on the ſubject, and to advertiſe myſelf vivâ voce.—I am, Sir, a Practitioner in Panegyric, or to ſpeak more plainly—a Profeſſor of the Art of Puffing, at your ſervice—or any body elſe's.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Sir, you are very obliging!—I believe, Mr. Puff, I have often admired your talents in the daily prints.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I flatter myſelf I do as much buſineſs in that way as any ſix of the fraternity in town—Deviliſh hard work all the ſummer—Friend Dangle? never work'd harder!—But harkee,—the Winter Managers were a little ſore I believe.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: No—I believe they took it all in good part.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Aye!—Then that muſt have been affectation in them, for egad, there were ſome of the attacks which there was no laughing at!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Aye, the humourous ones.—But I ſhould think Mr. Puff, that Authors would in general be able to do this ſort of work for themſelves.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Why yes—but in a clumſy way.—Beſides, we look on that as an encroachment, and ſo take the oppoſite ſide.—I dare ſay now you conceive half the very civil paragraphs and advertiſements you ſee, to be written by the parties concerned, or their friends?—No ſuch thing—Nine out of ten, manufactured by me in the way of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Indeed!—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
Even the Auctioneers now,—the Auctioneers I ſay, tho' the rogues have lately got ſome credit for their language—not an article of the merit their's!—take them out of their Pulpits, and they are as dull as Catalogues.—No, Sir;—'twas I firſt enrich'd their ſtyle—'twas I firſt taught them to crowd their advertiſements with panegyrical ſuperlatives, each epithet riſing above the other—like the Bidders in their own Auction-rooms! From ME they learn'd to enlay their phraſeology with variegated chips of exotic metaphor: by ME too their inventive faculties
were called forth.—Yes Sir, by ME they were inſtructed to clothe ideal walls with gratuitous fruits—to inſinuate obſequious rivulets into viſionary groves—to teach courteous ſhrubs to nod their approbation of the grateful ſoil! or on emergencies to raiſe upſtart oaks, where there never had been an acorn; to create a delightful vicinage without the aſſiſtance of a neighbour; or fix the temple of Hygeia in the fens of Lincolnſhire!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
SNEER.
sp.p: Service! if they had any gratitude, they would erect a ſtatue to him, they would figure him as a preſiding Mercury, the god of traffic and fiction, with a hammer in his hand inſtead of a caduceus.—But pray, Mr. Puff, what firſt put you on exerciſing your talents in this way?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Egad ſir,—ſheer neceſſity—the proper parent of an art ſo nearly allied to invention: you muſt know Mr. Sneer, that from the firſt time I tried my hand at an advertiſement, my ſucceſs was ſuch, that for ſometime after, I led a moſt extraordinary life indeed!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: How, pray?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Sir, I ſupported myſelf two years entirely by my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: By your misfortunes!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes Sir, aſſiſted by long ſickneſs, and other occaſional diſorders; and a very comfortable living I had of it.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: From ſickneſs and misfortunes!—You practiſed as a Doctor, and an Attorney at once?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No egad, both maladies and miſeries were my own.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Hey!—what the plague!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: 'Tis true, efaith.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Harkee!—By advertiſements—"To the charitable and humane!" and "to thoſe whom Providence hath bleſſed with affluence!"

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Oh,—I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: And in truth, I deſerved what I got, for I ſuppoſe never man went thro' ſuch a ſeries of calamities in the ſame ſpace of time!—Sir, I was five times made a bankrupt, and reduced from a ſtate of affluence, by a train of unavoidable misfortunes! then Sir, tho' a very induſtrious tradeſman, I was twice burnt out, and loſt my little all, both times!—I lived upon thoſe fires a month.—I ſoon after was confined by a moſt excruciating diſorder, and loſt the uſe of my limbs!—That told very well, for I had the caſe ſtrongly atteſted, and went about to collect the ſubſcriptions myſelf.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad, I believe that was when you firſt called on me.—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
—In November laſt?—O no!—I was at that time, a cloſe priſoner in the Marſhalſea, for a debt benevolently contracted to ſerve a friend!—I was afterwards, twice tapped for a dropſy, which declined into a very profitable conſumption!—I was then reduced to—O no—then, I became a widow with ſix helpleſs children,—after having had eleven huſbands preſſed, and being left every time eight months
gone with child, and without money to get me into an hoſpital!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: And you bore all with patience, I make no doubt?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Why, yes,—tho' I made ſome occaſional attempts at felo de ſe; but as I did not find thoſe raſh actions anſwer, I left off killing myſelf very ſoon.—Well, Sir,—at laſt, what with bankruptcies, fires, gouts, dropſies, impriſonments, and other valuable calamities, having got together a pretty handſome ſum, I determined to quit a buſineſs which had always gone rather againſt my conſcience, and in a more liberal way ſtill to indulge my talents for fiction and embelliſhment, thro' my favourite channels of diurnal communication—and ſo, Sir, you have my hiſtory.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Moſt obligingly communicative indeed; and your confeſſion if publiſhed, might certainly ſerve the cauſe of true charity, by reſcuing the moſt uſeful channels of appeal to benevolence from the cant of impoſition.—But ſurely, Mr. PUFF, there is no great myſtery in your preſent profeſſion?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Myſtery! Sir, I will take upon me to ſay the matter was never ſcientifically treated, nor reduced to rule before.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Reduced to rule?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O lud, Sir! you are very ignorant, I am afraid.—Yes Sir,—PUFFING is of various ſorts—the principal are, The PUFF DIRECT—the PUFF PRELIMINARY—the PUFF COLLATERAL—the PUFF COLLUSIVE, and the PUFF OBLIQUE, or PUFF by IMPLICATION.—Theſe all aſſume, as circumſtances require, the various forms of LETTER TO THE EDITOR—OCCASIONAL ANECDOTE—IMPARTIAL CRITIQUE—OBSERVATION from CORRESPONDENT,—or ADVERTISEMENT FROM THE PARTY.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: The puff direct, I can conceive—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
O yes, that's ſimple enough,—for inſtance—A new Comedy or Farce is to be produced at one of the Theatres (though by the bye they don't bring out half what they ought to do) The author, ſuppoſe Mr. Smatter, or Mr. Dapper—or any particular friend of mine—very well;
the day before it is to be performed, I write an account of the manner in which it was received—I have the plot from the author,—and only add—Characters ſtrongly drawn—highly coloured—hand of a maſter—fund of genuine humour—mine of invention—neat dialogue—attic ſalt! Then for the performance—Mr. DODD was aſtoniſhingly great in the character of SIR HARRY! That univerſal and judicious actor Mr. PALMER, perhaps never appeared to more advantage than in the COLONEL;—but it is not in the power of language to do juſtice to Mr. KING!—Indeed he more than merited thoſe repeated burſts of applauſe which he drew from a moſt brilliant and judicious audience! As to the ſcenery—The miraculous power of Mr. DE LOUTHER BOURG's pencil are univerſally acknowledged!—In ſhort, we are at a loſs which to admire moſt,—the unrivalled genius of the author, the great attention and liberality of the managers—the wonderful abilities of the painter, or the incredible exertions of all the performers!—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That's pretty well indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O cool—quite cool—to what I ſometimes do.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: And do you think there are any who are influenced by this.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O, lud! yes, Sir;—the number of thoſe who go thro' the fatigue of judging for themſelves is very ſmall indeed!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Well, Sir,—the PUFF PRELIMINARY?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
O that, Sir, does well in the form of a Caution.—In a matter of gallantry now—Sir FLIMSY GOSSIMER, wiſhes to be well with LADY FANNY FETE—He applies to me—I open trenches for him with a paragraph in the Morning Poſt.—It is recommended to the beautiful and accompliſhed Lady F four ſtars F daſh E to be on her guard againſt that dangerous character, Sir F daſh G; who, however pleaſing and inſinuating his manners may be, is certainly not remarkable for the conſtancy of his attachments!—in Italics.—Here you ſee, Sir FLIMSY GOSSIMER is introduced to the particular notice of Lady FANNY—who, perhaps never thought of him before—ſhe finds herſelf publickly cautioned to avoid him, which naturally makes her deſirous of ſeeing him;—the obſervation of their acquaintance cauſes a
pretty kind of mutual embarraſſment, this produces a ſort of ſympathy of intereſt—which, if Sir Flimſy is unable to improve effectually, he at leaſt gains the credit of having their names mentioned together, by a particular ſet, and in a particular way,—which nine times out of ten is the full accompliſhment of modern gallantry!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad, Sneer, you will be quite an adept in the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
Now, Sir, the PUFF COLLATERAL is much uſed as an appendage to advertiſements, and may take the form of anecdote.—Yeſterday as the celebrated GEORGE BON-MOT was ſauntering down St. James's-ſtreet, he met the lively Lady MARY MYRTLE, coming out of the Park,—'Good God, LADY MARY, I'm ſurpriſed to meet you in a white jacket,—for I expected never to have ſeen you, but in a full-trimmed unifor, and a light-horſeman's cap!'—"Heavens, GEORGE, where could you have learned that?"—'Why, replied the wit, I juſt ſaw a print of you, in a new publication called The CAMP MAGAZINE, which, by the bye, is a deviliſh clever thing,—and is ſold at No. 3, on the right hand of the way, two doors from the
printing-office, the corner of Ivy-lane, Pater-noſter-row, price only one ſhilling!'

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Very ingenious indeed!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: But the PUFF COLLUSIVE is the neweſt of any; for it acts in the diſguiſe of determined hoſtility.—It is much uſed by bold bookſellers and enterpriſing poets.—An indignant correſpondent obſerves—that the new poem called BEELZEBUB's COTILLION, or PROSERPINE's FETE CHAMPETRE, is one of the moſt unjuſtifiable performances he ever read! The ſeverity with which certain characters are handled is quite ſhocking! And as there are many deſcriptions in it too warmly coloured for female delicacy, the ſhameful avidity with which this piece is bought by all people of faſhion, is a reproach on the taſte of the times, and a diſgrace to the delicacy of the age!—Here you ſee the two ſtrongeſt inducements are held forth;—Firſt, that nobody ought to read it;—and ſecondly, that every body buys it; on the ſtrength of which, the publiſher boldly prints the tenth edition, before the had ſold ten of the firſt; and then eſtabliſhes it by threatening himſelf with the pillory, or abſolutely indicting himſeif for SCAN. MAG.!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—'gad I know it is ſo▪

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
As to the PUFF OBLIQUE, or PUFF BY IMPLICATION, it is too various and extenſive to be illuſtrated by an inſtance;—it attracts in titles, and preſumes in patents; it lurks in the limitation of a ſubſcription, and invites in the aſſurance of croud and incommodation at public places; it delights to draw forth concealed merit, with a moſt diſintereſted aſſiduity; and ſometimes wears a countenance of ſmiling cenſure and tender reproach.—It has a wonderful memory for Parliamentary Debates, and will often give the whole ſpeech of a favoured member, with the moſt flattering accuracy. But, above all, it is a great dealer in reports and ſuppoſitions.—It has the earlieſt intelligence of intended preferments that will reflect honor on the patrons; and embryo promotions of modeſt gentlemen—who know nothing of the matter themſelves. It can hint a ribband for implied ſervices, in the air of a common report; and with the careleſneſs of a caſual paragraph, ſuggeſt officers into commands—to which they have no pretenſion but their wiſhes. This, Sir, is the laſt principal claſs in the ART of PUFFING—An art which I hope you will
now agree with me, is of the higheſt dignity—yielding a tablature of benevolence and public ſpirit; befriending equally trade, gallantry, criticiſm, and politics:—the applauſe of genius! the regiſter of charity! the triumph of heroiſm! the ſelf defence of contractors! the fame of orators!—and the gazette of miniſters!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Sir, I am compleatly a convert both to the importance and ingenuity of your profeſſion; and now, Sir, there is but one thing which can poſſibly encreaſe my reſpect for you, and that is, your permitting me to be preſent this morning at the rehearſal of your new trage—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: —Huſh, for heaven's ſake.—My tragedy!—Egad, Dangle, I take this very ill—you know how apprehenſive I am of being known to be the author.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: 'Efaith I would not have told—but it's in the papers, and your name at length—in the Morning Chronicle.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Ah! thoſe damn'd editors never can keep a ſecret!—Well, Mr. Sneer—no doubt you will do me great honour—I ſhall be infinitely happy—highly flattered—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: I believe it muſt be near the time—ſhall we go together.

sp.speaker: FUFF.
sp.p: No; It will not be yet this hour, for they are always late at that theatre: beſides, I muſt meet you there, for I have ſome little matters here to ſend to the papers, and a few paragraphs to ſcribble before I go. [Looking at memorandums.

—Here is 'a CONSCIENTIOUS BAKER, on the Subject of the Army Bread;' and 'a DETESTER OF VISIBLE BRICK-WORK, in favor of the new invented Stucco;' both in the ſtyle of JUNIUS, and promiſed for to-morrow.—The Thames navigation too is at a ſtand—MISOMUD or ANTI-SHOAL muſt go to work again directly. —Here too are ſome political memorandums I ſee; aye—To take PAUL JONES, and get the INDIAMEN out of the SHANNON—reinforce BYRON—compel the DUTCH to—ſo!—I muſt do that in the evening papers, or reſerve it for the Morning Herald, for I know that I have undertaken to-morrow; beſides, to eſtabliſh the unanimity of the fleet in the Public Advertiſer, and to ſhoot CHARLES Fox in the Morning Poſt.—So, egad, I ha'n't a moment to loſe!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Well!—we'll meet in the Green Room.

div.head: SCENE I.
The THEATRE.
div.stage: Enter DANGLE, PUFF, and SNEER, as before the Curtain.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: NO, no, Sir; what Shakeſpeare ſays of ACTORS may be better applied to the purpoſe of PLAYS; they ought to be 'the abſtract and brief Chronicles of the times.' Therefore when hiſtory, and particularly the hiſtory of our own country, furniſhes any thing like a caſe in point, to the time in which an author writes, if he knows his own intereſt, he will take advantage of it; ſo, Sir, I call my tragedy The SPANISH ARMADA; and have laid the ſcene before TILBURY FORT.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: A moſt happy thought certainly!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad it was—I told you ſo.—But pray now I dont underſtand how you have contrived to introduce any love into it.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Love!—Oh nothing ſo eaſy; for it is a received point among poets, that where hiſtory gives you a good heroic out-line for a play, you may fill up with a little love at your own diſcretion; in doing which, nine times out of ten, you only make up a deficiency in the private hiſtory of the times.—Now I rather think I have done this with ſome ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No ſcandal about Queen ELIZABETH, I hope?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O Lud! no, no.—I only ſuppoſe the Governor of Tilbury Fort's daughter to be in love with the ſon of the Spaniſh Admiral.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Oh, is that all?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Excellent, Efaith!—I ſee it at once.—But won't this appear rather improbable?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure it will—but what the plague! a play is not to ſhew occurrences that happen every day, but things juſt ſo ſtrange, that tho' they never did, they might happen.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Certainly nothing is unnatural, that is not phyſically impoſſible.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Very true—and for that matter DON FEROLO WISKERANDOS—for that's the lover's name, might have been over here in the train of the Spaniſh Ambaſſador; or TILBURINA, for that is the lady's name, might have been in love with him, from having heard his character, or ſeen his picture; or from knowing that he was the laſt man in the world ſhe ought to be in love with—or for any other good female reaſon.—However, Sir, the fact is, that tho' ſhe is but a Knight's daughter, egad! ſhe is in love like any Princeſs!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Poor young lady! I feel for her already! for I can conceive how great the conflict muſt be between her paſſion and her duty; her love for her country, and her love for DON FEROLO WISKERANDOS!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O amazing!—her poor ſuſceptible heart is ſwayed to and fro, by contending paſſions like—

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Sir, the ſcene is ſet, and every thing is ready to begin if you pleaſe.—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: 'Egad; then we'll loſe no time.

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Tho' I believe, Sir, you will find it very ſhort, for all the performers have profited by the kind permiſſion you granted them.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Hey! what!

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: You know, Sir, you gave them leave to cut out or omit whatever they found heavy or unneceſſary to the plot, and I muſt own they have taken very liberal advantage of your indulgence.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Well, well.—They are in general very good judges; and I know I am luxuriant.—Now, Mr. HOPKINS, as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER to the Muſick.
sp.p: Gentlemen, will you play a few bars of ſomething, juſt to—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Aye, that's right,—for as we have the ſcenes, and dreſſes, egad, we'll go to't, as if it was the firſt night's performance;—but you need not mind ſtopping between the acts.

div.p: Soh! ſtand clear gentlemen.—Now you know there will be a cry of down!—down!—hats off! ſilence!—Then up curtain,—and let us ſee what our painters have done for us.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: The Curtain riſes and diſcovers TILBURY FORT. Two Centinels aſleep.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Tilbury Fort!—very fine indeed!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now, what do you think I open with?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Faith, I can't gueſs—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
A clock.—Hark!—(clock ſtrikes.) I open with a clock ſtriking, to beget an aweful attention
in the audience—it alſo marks the time, which is four o'clock in the morning, and ſaves a deſcription of the riſing fun, and a great deal about gilding the eaſtern hemiſphere.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But pray, are the centinels to be aſleep?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Faſt as watchmen.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Isn't that odd tho' at ſuch an alarming criſis?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure it is,—but ſmaller things muſt give way to a ſtriking ſcene at the opening; that's a rule.—And the caſe is, that two great men are coming to this very ſpot to begin the piece; now, it is not to be ſuppoſed they would open their lips, if theſe fellows were watching them, ſo, egad, I muſt either have ſent them off their poſts, or ſet them aſleep.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: O that accounts for it!—But tell us, who are theſe coming?—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
Theſe are they—SIR WALTER RALEIGH, and SIR CHRISTOPHER HATTON.—You'll know Sir
CHRISTOPHER, by his turning out his toes—famous you know for his dancing. I like to preſerve all the little traits of character.—Now attend.

div.stage: Enter Sir WALTER RALEIGH and Sir CHRISTOPHER HATTON.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: True, gallant Raleigh!—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: What, they had been talking before?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O, yes; all the way as they came along.—I beg pardon gentlemen [to the Actors] but theſe are particular friends of mine, whoſe remarks may be of great ſervice to us.—Don't mind interrupting them whenever any thing ſtrikes you.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: True, gallant Raleigh!
But O, thou champion of thy country's fame,
There is a queſtion which I yet muſt aſk;
A queſtion, which I never aſk'd before—
What mean theſe mighty armaments?
This general muſter? and this throng of chiefs?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Puff, how came Sir Chriſtopher Hatton never to aſk that queſtion before?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: What, before the Play began? how the plague could he?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's true efaith!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: But you will hear what he thinks of the matter.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: Alas, my noble friend, when I behold
Yon tented plains in martial ſymmetry
Array'd.—When I count o'er yon glittering lines
Of creſted warriors, where the proud ſteeds neigh,
And valor-breathing trumpet's ſhrill appeal,
Reſponſive vibrate on my liſtning ear;
When virgin majeſty herſelf I view,
Like her protecting Pallas veil'd in ſteel,
With graceful confidence exhort to arms!
When briefly all I hear or ſee bears ſtamp
Of martial vigilance, and ſtern defence,
I cannot but ſurmiſe.—Forgive, my friend,
If the conjecture's raſh—I cannot but
Surmiſe.—Then ſtate ſome danger apprehends!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: A very cautious conjecture that.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, that's his character; not to give an opinion, but on ſecure grounds—now then.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: O, moſt accompliſhed Chriſtopher.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: He calls him by his chriſtian name, to ſhew that they are on the moſt familiar terms.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: O moſt accompliſh'd Chriſtopher, I find
Thy ſtaunch ſagacity ſtill tracks the future,
In the freſh print of the o'ertaken paſt.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Figurative!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: Thy fears are juſt.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: But where? whence? when? and what
The danger is—Methinks I fain would learn.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: You know, my friend, ſcarce two revolving ſuns,
And three revolving moons, have cloſed their courſe,
Since haughty PHILIP, in deſpight of peace,
With hoſtile hand hath ſtruck at ENGLAND's trade.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: I know it well.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: PHILIP you know is proud, IBERIA's king!

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: —His ſubjects in baſe bigotry
And Catholic oppreſſion held,—while we
You know, the proteſtant perſuaſion hold.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: You know beſide,—his boaſted armament,
The fam'd Armada,—by the Pope baptized,
With purpoſe to invade theſe realms—

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: —Is ſailed,
Our laſt advices ſo report.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: While the Iberian Admiral's chief hope,
His darling ſon—

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER,
sp.l: —Ferolo Wiſkerandos hight—

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: The ſame—by chance a pris'ner hath been ta'en,
And in this fort of Tilbury—

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: —Is now
Confin'd,—'tis true, and oft from you tall turrets top
I've mark'd the youthful Spaniard's haughty mien
Unconquer'd, tho' in chains!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: You alſo know—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: —Mr. Puff, as he knows all this, why does Sir Walter go on telling him?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: But the audience are not ſuppoſed to know any thing of the matter, are they?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: True, but I think you manage ill: for there certainly appears no reaſon why Sir Walter ſhould be ſo communicative.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: For, egad now, that is one of the moſt ungrateful obſervations I ever heard—for the leſs inducement he has to tell all th • s, the more I think, you ought to be oblig'd to him; for I am ſure you'd know nothing of the matter without it.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's very true, upon my word.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: But you will find he was not going on.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: Enough, enough,—'tis plain—and I no more
Am in amazement loſt!—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Here, now you ſee, Sir Chriſtopher did not in fact aſk any one queſtion for his own information.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No indeed:—his has been a moſt diſintereſted curioſity!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Really, I find, we are very much oblig'd to them both.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure you are. Now then for the Commander in Chief, the EARL OF LEICESTER! who, you know, was no favourite but of the Queen's.—We left off—"in amazement loſt!"—

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: Am in amazement loſt.—
But, ſee where noble Leiceſter comes! ſupreme
In honours and command.

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: And yet methinks,
At ſuch a time, ſo perilous, ſo fear'd,
That ſtaff might well become an abler graſp.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: And ſo by heav'n! think I; but ſoft, he's here!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Aye, they envy him.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But who are theſe with him?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O! very valiant knights; one is the Governor of the fort, the other the maſter of the horſe.—And now, I think you ſhall hear ſome better language: I was obliged to be plain and intelligible in the firſt ſcene, becauſe there was ſo much matter of fact in it; but now, efaith, you have trope, figure, and metaphor, as plenty as noun-ſubſtantives.

div.stage: Enter Earl of LEICESTER, the Governor, and others.

sp.speaker: LEICESTER.
sp.l: How's this my friends! is't thus your new fledg'd zeal
And plumed valor moulds in rooſted-ſloth?
Why dimly glimmers that heroic flame,
Whoſe red'ning blaze by patriot ſpirit fed,
Should be the beacon of a kindling realm?
Can the quick current of a patriot heart,
Thus ſtagnate in a cold and weedy converſe,
Or freeze in tideleſs inactivity?
No! rather let the fountain of your valor
Spring thro' each ſtream of enterprize,
Each petty channel of conducive daring,
Till the full torrent of your foaming wrath
O'erwhelm the flats of ſunk hoſtility!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There it is,—follow'd up!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: No more! the freſh'ning breath of thy rebuke
Hath fill'd the ſwelling canvaſs of our ſouls!
And thus, tho' fate ſhould cut the cable of
Our topmoſt hopes, in friendſhip's cloſing line
We'll grapple with deſpair, and if we fall,
We'll fall in Glory's wake!

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: There ſpoke Old England's genius!
Then, are we all reſolv'd?

sp.speaker: ALL,
sp.l: We are—all reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: To conquer—or be free?

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.l: To conquer, or be free.

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Nem. con. egad!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O yes, where they do agree on the ſtage, their unanimity is wonderful!

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: Then, let's embrace—and now—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What the plague, is he going to pray?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, huſh!—in great emergencies, there is nothing like a prayer!

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: O mighty Mars!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But why ſhould he pray to Mars?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.l: Huſh!

sp.speaker: EARL OF LEICESTER.
sp.l: If in thy homage bred,
Each point of diſcipline I've ſtill obſerv'd;
Nor but by due promotion, and the right
Of ſervice, to the rank of Major-General
Have ris'n; aſſiſt thy votary now!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Yet do not riſe,—hear me!

sp.speaker: MASTER OF HORSE.
sp.l: And me!

sp.speaker: KNIGHT.
sp.l: And me!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: And me!

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: And me!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now, pray all together.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.l: Behold thy votaries ſubmiſſive beg,
That thou will deign to grant them all they aſk;
Aſſiſt them to accompliſh all their ends,
And ſanctify whatever means they uſe
To gain them!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: A very orthodox quintetto!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Vaſtly well, gentlemen.—Is that well managed or not? Have you ſuch a prayer as that on the ſtage?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Not exactly.
But, Sir, you hav'nt ſettled how we are to get off here.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: You could not go off kneeling, could you?
O no, Sir! impoſſible!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: It would have a good effect efaith, if you could! exeunt praying!—Yes, and would vary the eſtabliſhed mode of ſpringing off with a glance at the pit.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: O never mind, ſo as you get them off, I'll anſwer for it the audience wont care how.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Well then, repeat the laſt line ſtanding, and go off the old way.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.l: And ſanctify whatever means we uſe to gain them.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Bravo! a fine exit.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Well, really Mr. Puff.—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Stay a moment.—

sp.speaker: 1ſt CENTINEL.
sp.l: All this ſhall to Lord Burleigh's ear.

sp.speaker: 2d CENTINEL.
sp.l: 'Tis meet it ſhould.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Hey!—why, I thought thoſe fellows had been aſleep?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Only a pretence, there's the art of it; they were ſpies of Lord Burleigh's.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: —But isn't it odd, they were never taken notice of, not even by the commander in chief.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O lud, Sir, if people who want to liſten, or overhear, were not always conniv'd at in a Tragedy, there would be no carrying on any plot in the world.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's certain!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: But take care, my dear Dangle, the morning gun is going to fire.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Well, that will have a fine effect.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: I think ſo, and helps to realize the ſcene.—

What the plague!—three morning guns!—there never is but one!—aye, this is always the
away at the Theatre—give theſe fellows a good thing, and they never know when to have done with it. You have no more cannon to fire?

sp.speaker: PROMPTER from within.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now then, for ſoft muſick.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Pray what's that for?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: It ſhews that TILBURINA is coming; nothing introduces you a heroine like ſoft muſick.—Here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: And her confidant, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure: here they are—inconſolable to the minuet in Ariadne!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Now has the whiſpering breath of gentle morn,
Bad Nature's voice, and Nature's beauty riſe;
While orient Phoebus with unborrow'd hues,
Cloaths the wak'd lovelineſs which all night ſlept
In heav'nly drapery! Darkneſs is fled.
Now flowers unfold their beauties to the ſun,
And bluſhing, kiſs the beam he ſends to wake them.
The ſtrip'd carnation, and the guarded roſe,
The vulgar wall flow'r, and ſmart gillyflower,
The polyanthus mean—the dapper daizy,
Sweet William, and ſweet marjorum,—and all
The tribe of ſingle and of double pinks!
Now too, the feather'd warblers tune their notes
Around, and charm the liſtning grove.—The lark!
The linnet! chafinch! bullfinch! goldfinch! greenfinch!
—But O to me, no joy can they afford!
Nor roſe, nor wall flow'r, nor ſmart gillyflower,
Nor polyanthus mean, nor dapper daizy,
Nor William ſweet, nor marjoram—nor lark,
Linnet, nor all the finches of the grove!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Your white handkerchief madam—

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.p: I thought, Sir, I wasn't to uſe that'till, 'heart rending woe.'

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O yes madam—at 'the finches of the grove,' if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Nor lark,
Linnet, nor all the finches of the grove!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Vaſtly well madam!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Vaſtly well indeed!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: For, O too ſure, heart rending woe is now
The lot of wretched Tilburina!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: O!—'tis too much.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Oh!—it is indeed

sp.speaker: CONFIDANT.
sp.l: Be comforted ſweet lady—for who knows,
But Heav'n has yet ſome milk-white day in ſtore.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Alas, my gentle Nofa,
Thy tender youth, as yet hath never mourn'd
Love's fatal dart.—Elſe wouldſt thou know, that when
The ſoul is ſunk in comfortleſs deſpair,
It cannot taſte of merryment!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's certain.

sp.speaker: CONFIDANT.
sp.l: But ſee where your ſtern father comes;
It is not meet that he ſhould find you thus.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Hey, what the plague!—what a cut is here!—why, what is become of the deſcription of her firſt meeting with Don Wiſkerandos? his gallant behaviour in the ſea fight, and the ſimile of the canary bird?

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Indeed Sir, you'll find they will not be miſs'd.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.l: Very well.—Very well!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: The cue ma'am if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: CONFIDANT.
sp.l: It is not meet that he ſhould find you thus.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Thou counſel'ſt right, but 'tis no eaſy taſk
For barefaced grief to wear a maſk of joy.

sp.speaker: Enter GOVERNOR.
sp.l: How's this—in tears?—O Tilburina, ſhame!
Is this a time for maudling tenderneſs,
And Cupid's baby woes?—haſt thou not heard
That haughty Spain's Pope-conſecrated fleet
Advances to our ſhores, while England's fate,
Like a clipp'd guinca, trembles in the ſcale!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Then, is the criſis of my fate at hand!
I ſee the fleets approach—I ſee—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now, pray gentlemen mind.—This is one of the moſt uſeful figures we tragedy writers have, by which a hero or heroine, in conſideration of their being often obliged to overlook things that are on the ſtage, is allow'd to hear and ſee a number of things that are not.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Yes—a kind of poetical ſecond-ſight!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes—now then madam.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: I ſee their decks
Are clear'd!—I ſee the ſignal made!
The line is form'd!—a cable's length aſunder!
I ſee the frigates ſtation'd in the rear;
And now, I hear the thunder of the guns!
I hear the victors ſhouts—I alſo hear
The vanquiſh'd groan!—and now 'tis ſmoke—and now
I ſee the looſe ſails ſhiver in the wind!
I ſee—I ſee—what ſoon you'll ſee—

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Hold daughter! peace! this love hath turn'd thy brain:
The Spaniſh fleet thou canſt not ſee—becauſe
—It is not yet in ſight!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Egad tho', the governor ſeems to make no allowance for this poetical figure you talk of.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No, a plain matter-of-fact man—that's his character.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: But will you then refuſe his offer?

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: I muſt—I will—I can—I ought—I do.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Think what a noble price.

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: No more—you urge in vain.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: His liberty is all he aſks.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: All who aſks Mr. Puff? Who is—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Egad Sir, I can't tell.—Here has been ſuch cutting and ſlaſhing, I don't know where they have got to myſelf.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, you will find it will connect very well.
sp.l: —And your reward ſecure.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O,—if they had'nt been ſo deviliſh free with their cutting here, you would have found that Don Wiſkerandos has been tampering for his liberty, and has perſuaded Tilburina to make this propoſal to her father—and now pray obſerve the conciſeneſs with which the argument is conducted. Egad, the pro & con goes as ſmart a hits in a fencing match. It is indeed a ſort of ſmall-ſword logic, which we have borrowed from the French.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: A retreat in Spain!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Outlawry here!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Your daughter's prayer!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Your father's oath!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: My lover!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: My country!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Tilburina!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: England!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: A title!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Honor!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: A penſion!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Conſcience!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: A thouſand pounds!

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: Hah! thou haſt touch'd me nearly!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There you ſee—ſhe threw in Tilburina, Quick, parry cart with England!—Hah! thruſt in teirce a title!—parried by honor.—Hah! a penſion over the arm!—put by by conſcience.—Then flankonade with a thouſand pounds—and a palpable hit egad!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Canſt thou—
Reject the ſuppliant, and the daughter too?

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: No more; I wou'd not hear thee plead in vain,
The father ſoftens—but the governor
Is fix'd!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Aye, that antitheſis of perſons—is a moſt eſtabliſh'd figure.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Tis well,—hence then fond hopes,—fond paſſion hence;
Duty, behold I am all over thine—

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS without.
sp.l: Where is my love—my—

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS entering.
sp.l: My beauteous enemy—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O dear ma'am, you muſt ſtart a great deal more than that; conſider you had juſt determined in favour of duty—when in a moment the ſound of his voice revives your paſſion,—overthrows your reſolution, deſtroys your obedience.—If you don't expreſs all that in your ſtart—you do nothing at all.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Well, we'll try again!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Speaking from within, has always a fine effect.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS.
sp.l: My conquering Tilburina! How! is't thus
We meet? why are thy looks averſe! what means
That falling tear—that frown of boding woe?
Hah! now indeed I am a priſoner!
Yes, now I feel the galling weight of theſe
Diſgraceful chains—which, cruel Tilburina!
Thy doating captive gloried in before.—
But thou art falſe, and Wiſkerandos is undone!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: O no; how little doſt thou know thy Tilburina!

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS.
sp.l: Art thou then true? Begone cares, doubts and fears,
I make you all a preſent to the winds;
And if the winds reject you—try the waves.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: The wind you know, is the eſtabliſhed receiver of all ſtolen ſighs, and caſt off griefs and apprehenſions.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Yet muſt we part?—ſtern duty ſeals our doom:
Though here I call yon conſcious clouds to witneſs,
Could I purſue the bias of my ſoul,
All friends, all right of parents I'd diſclaim,
And thou, my Wiſkerandos, ſhould'ſt be father
And mother, brother, couſin, uncle, aunt,
And friend to me!

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS.
sp.l: O matchleſs excellence!—and muſt we part?
Well, if—we muſt—we muſt—and in that caſe,
The leſs is ſaid the better.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Hey day! here's a cut!—What, are all the mutual proteſtations out?

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.p: Now, pray Sir, don't interrupt us juſt here, you ruin our feelings.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Your feelings!—but zounds, my feelings, ma'am!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No; pray don't interrupt them.

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS.
sp.l: One laſt embrace.—

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Now,—farewell, for ever.

sp.speaker: WISKERANDOS.
sp.l: For ever!

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: Aye, for ever.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: S'death and fury!—Gadſlife! Sir! Madam! if you go out without the parting look, you might as well dance out—Here, here!

sp.speaker: CONFIDANT.
sp.l: But pray Sir, how am I to get off here?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: You, pſhaw! what the devil ſignifies how you get off! edge away at the top, or where you will— [Puſhes the confidant off.] Now ma'am you ſee—

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.p: We underſtand you Sir.
Aye for ever.

sp.speaker: BOTH.
sp.p: Ohh!—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: O charming!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Hey!—'tis pretty well I believe—you ſee I don't attempt to ſtrike out any thing new—but I take it I improve on the eſtabliſhed modes.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: You do indeed.—But pray is not Queen Elizabeth to appear?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No not once—but ſhe is to be talked of for ever; ſo that egad you'll think a hundred times that ſhe is on the point of coming in.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Hang it, I think its a pity to keep her in the green room all the night.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O no, that always has a fine effect—it keeps up expectation.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: But are we not to have a battle?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you will have a battle at laſt, but, egad, it's not to be by land—but by ſea—and that is the only quite new thing in the piece.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: What, Drake at the Armada, hey?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, efaith—fire ſhips and all—then we ſhall end with the proceſſion.—Hey! that will do I think.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Come, we muſt not loſe time—ſo now for the UNDER PLOT.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What the plague, have you another plot?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
O lord, yes—ever while you live, have two plots to your tragedy.—The grand point in managing them, is only to let your under plot have as little connexion with your main plot as poſſible. —I flatter myſelf nothing can be more diſtinct than mine, for as in my chief plot, the
characters are all great people—I have laid my under plot in low life—and as the former is to end in deep diſtreſs, I make the other end as happy as a farce.—Now Mr. Hopkins, as ſoon as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Enter UNDER PROMPTER. UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Sir, the carpenter ſays it is impoſſible you can go to the Park ſcene yet.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: The Park ſcene! No—I mean the deſcription ſcene here, in the wood.

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Sir, the performers have cut it out.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Cut it out!

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: What! the whole account of Queen Elizabeth?

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: And the deſcription of her horſe and ſide-ſaddle?

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: So, ſo, this is very fine indeed! Mr. Hopkins, how the plague could you ſuffer this?

sp.speaker: HOPKINS, from within.
sp.p: Sir, indeed the pruning knife—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: The pruning knife—zounds the axe! why, here has been ſuch lopping and topping, I ſhan't have the bare trunk of my play left preſently.—Very well, Sir—the performers muſt do as they pleaſe, but upon my ſoul, I'll print it every word.
