sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That I would indeed.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Very well—Sir—then we muſt go on—zounds! I would not have parted with the deſcription of the horſe!—Well, Sir, go on—Sir, it was one of the fineſt and moſt laboured things—Very well, Sir, let them go on—there you had him and his accoutrements from the bit to the crupper —very well, Sir, we muſt go to the Park ſcene.

sp.speaker: UNDER PROMPTER.
sp.p: Sir, there is the point, the carpenters ſay, that unleſs there is ſome buſineſs put in here before the drop, they ſhan't have time to clear away the fort, or ſink Graveſend and the river.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: So! this is a pretty dilemma truly!—Gentlemen —you muſt excuſe me, theſe fellows will never be ready, unleſs I go and look after them myſelf.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: O dear Sir—theſe little things will happen—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To cut out this ſcene!—but I'll print it—egad, I'll print it every word! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.
Before the Curtain.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: WELL, we are ready—now then for the juſtices.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: This, I ſuppoſe, is a ſort of ſenate ſcene.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure—there has not been one yet.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: It is the under plot, isn't it?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes. What, gentlemen, do you mean to go at once to the diſcovery ſcene?

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O very well—harkee, I don't chuſe to ſay any thing more, but efaith, they have mangled my play in a moſt ſhocking manner!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: It's a great pity!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now then, Mr. Juſtice, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: Are all the volunteers without?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE.
sp.l: They are.
Some ten in fetters, and ſome twenty drunk.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: Attends the youth, whoſe moſt opprobrious fame
And clear convicted crimes have ſtampt him ſoldier?

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE.
sp.l: He waits your pleaſure; eager to repay
The bleſt reprieve that ſends him to the fields
Of glory, there to raiſe his branded hand
In honor's cauſe.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: 'Tis well—'tis Juſtice arms him!
O! may he now defend his country's laws
With half the ſpirit he has broke them all!
If 'tis your worſhip's pleaſure, bid him enter.

sp.speaker: CONSTABLE.
sp.l: I fly, the herald of your will.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Quick, Sir!—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But, Mr. Puff, I think not only the Juſtice, but the clown ſeems to talk in as high a ſtyle as the firſt hero among them.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Heaven forbid they ſhould not in a free country!—Sir, I am not for making ſlaviſh diſtinctions, and giving all the fine language to the upper ſort of people.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's very noble in you indeed.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now pray mark this ſcene.

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.l: Forgive this interruption, good my love;
But as I juſt now paſt, a pris'ner youth
Whom rude hands hither lead, ſtrange bodings ſeiz'd
My fluttering heart, and to myſelf I ſaid,
An if our TOM had liv'd, he'd ſurely been
This ſtripling's height!

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: Ha! ſure ſome powerful ſympathy directs
Us both—

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.l: My name's TOM JENKINS—alias, have I none—
Tho' orphan'd, and without a friend!

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: Thy parents?
son.
My father dwelt in Rocheſter—and was,
As I have heard—a fiſhmonger—no more.

sp.speaker: PUFF
sp.p: What, Sir, do you leave out the account of your birth, parentage and education?

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.p: They have ſettled it ſo, Sir, here.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.l: How loudly nature whiſpers to my heart!
Had he no other name?

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.l: I've ſeen a bill
Of his, ſign'd Tomkins, creditor.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: This does indeed confirm each circumſtance
The gypſey told!—Prepare!

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: No orphan, nor without a friend ar't thou—
I am thy father, here's thy mother, there
Thy uncle—this thy firſt couſin, and thoſe
Are all your near relations!

sp.speaker: MOTHER.
sp.l: O ecſtaſy of bliſs!

sp.speaker: SON.
sp.l: O moſt unlook'd for happineſs!

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: O wonderful event!
sp.stage: [They faint alternately in each others arms.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There, you ſee relationſhip, like murder, will out.

sp.speaker: JUSTICE.
sp.l: Now let's revive—elſe were this joy too much!
But come—and we'll unfold the reſt within,
And thou my boy muſt needs want reſt and food.
Hence may each orphan hope, as chance directs,
To find a father—where he leaſt expects!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: What do you think of that?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: One of the fineſt diſcovery-ſcenes I ever ſaw. —Why, this under-plot would have made a tragedy itſelf.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Aye, or a comedy either.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: And keeps quite clear you ſee of the other.
sp.stage: Enter SCENEMEN, taking away the Seats.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: The ſcene remains, does it?

sp.speaker: SCENEMAN.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
You are to leave one chair you know—But it is always awkward in a tragedy, to have you
fellows coming in in your playhouſe liveries to remove things—I wiſh that could be managed better.—So now for my myſterious yeoman.

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.p: Perdition catch my ſoul but I do love thee.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Haven't I heard that line before?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No, I fancy not—Where pray?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Yes, I think there is ſomething like it in Othello.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Gad! now you put me in mind on't, I believe there is—but that's of no conſequence—all that can be ſaid is, that two people happened to hit on the ſame thought—And Shakeſpeare made uſe of it firſt, that's all.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now, Sir, your ſoliloquy—but ſpeak more to the pit, if you pleaſe—the ſoliloquy always to the pit—that's a rule.

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: Tho' hopeleſs love finds comfort in deſpair,
It never can endure a rival's bliſs!
But ſoft—I am obſerv'd. [Exit Beefeater.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's a very ſhort ſoliloquy.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes—but it would have been a great deal longer if he had not been obſerved.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: A moſt ſentimental Beefeater that, Mr. Puff.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Hearke—I would not have you be too ſure that he is a Beefeater.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What! a hero in diſguiſe?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No matter—I only give you a hint—But now for my principal character—Here he comes—LORD BURLEIGH in perſon! Pray, gentlemen, ſtep this way—ſoftly—I only hope the Lord High Treaſurer is perfect—if he is but perfect!
sp.stage: [Enter BURLEIGH, goes ſlowly to a chair and ſits.]

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Mr. Puff!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Huſh!—vaſtly well, Sir! vaſtly well! a moſt intereſting gravity!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: What, isn't he to ſpeak at all?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
Egad, I thought you'd aſk me that—yes it is a very likely thing—that a Miniſter in his ſituation,
with the whole affairs of the nation on his head, ſhould have time to talk!—but huſh! or you'll put him out.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Put him out! how the plague can that be, if he's not going to ſay any thing?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There's a reaſon!—why, his part is to think, and how the plague! do you imagine he can think if you keep talking?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's very true upon my word!
sp.stage: [Burleigh comes forward, ſhakes his head and exit.]

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: He is very perfect indeed—Now, pray what did he mean by that?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: You don't take it?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: No; I don't upon my ſoul.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Why, by that ſhake of the head, he gave you to underſtand that even tho' they had more juſtice in their cauſe and wiſdom in their meaſures—yet, if there was not a greater ſpirit ſhown on the part of the people—the country would at laſt fall a ſacrifice to the hoſtile ambition of the Spaniſh monarchy.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: The devil!—did he mean all that by ſhaking his head?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Every word of it—If he ſhook his head as I taught him.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Ah! there certainly is a vaſt deal to be done on the ſtage by dumb ſhew, and expreſſion of face, and a judicious author knows how much he may truſt to it.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: O, here are ſome of our old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: My niece, and your niece too!
By heav'n! there's witchcraft in't—He could not elſe
Have gain'd their hearts—But ſee where they approach;
Some horrid purpoſe low'ring on their brows!

sp.speaker: SIR WALTER.
sp.l: Let us withdraw and mark them.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What is all this?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p:
Ah! here has been more pruning!—but the fact is, theſe two young ladies are alſo in love with Don Whiſkerandos.—Now, gentlemen, this ſcene
goes entirely for what we call SITUATION and STAGE EFFECT, by which the greateſt applauſe may be obtained, without the aſſiſtance of language, ſentiment or character: pray mark!

sp.speaker: 1ſt NIECE.
sp.l: Ellena here!
She is his ſcorn as much as I—that is
Some comfort ſtill.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O dear madam, you are not to ſay that to her face!—aſide, ma'am, aſide.—The whole ſcene is to be aſide.

sp.speaker: 1ſt NIECE.
sp.l: She is his ſcorn as much as I—that is
Some comfort ſtill!

sp.speaker: 2d NIECE.
sp.l: I know he prizes not Pollina's love,
But Tilburina lords it o'er his heart.

sp.speaker: 1ſt NIECE.
sp.l: But ſee the proud deſtroyer of my peace.
Revenge is all the good I've left.

sp.speaker: 2d NIECE.
sp.l: He comes, the falſe diſturber of my quiet.
Now vengeance do thy worſt—
O hateful liberty—if thus in vain
I ſeek my Tilburina!

sp.speaker: BOTH NIECES.
sp.l: And ever ſhalt!
SIR CHRISTOPHER AND SIR WALTER come forward.
Hold! we will avenge you.

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: Hold you—or ſee your nieces bleed.!
sp.stage: [The two nieces draw their two daggers to ſtrike Whiſkerandos, the two Uncles at the inſtant with their two ſwords drawn, catch their two nieces arms, and turn the points of their ſwords to Whiſkerandos, who immediately draws two daggers, and holds them to the two nieces' boſoms.]

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There's ſituation for you!—there's an heroic group!—You ſee the ladies can't ſtab Whiſkerandos —he durſt not ſtrike them for fear of their uncles—the uncles durſt not kill him, becauſe of their nieces—I have them all at a dead lock!—for every one of them is afraid to let go firſt.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Why, then they muſt ſtand there for ever.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: So they would, if I hadn't a very fine contrivance for't—Now mind—

sp.l: In the Queen's name I charge you all to drop
Your ſwords and daggers!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: That is a contrivance indeed.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Aye—in the Queen's name.

sp.speaker: SIR CHRISTOPHER.
sp.l: Come niece!

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: What's he, who bids us thus renounce our guard?

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: Thou muſt do more, renounce thy love!

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: Thou lieſt—baſe Beefeater!

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: Ha! Hell! the lie!
By heav'n thou'ſt rous'd the lion in my heart!
Off yeoman's habit!—baſe diſguiſe!—off! off!
sp.stage: [Diſcovers himſelf, by throwing off his upper dreſs, and appearing in a very fine waiſtcoat.]
sp.l: Am I a Beefeater now?
Or beams my creſt as terrible as when
In Biſcay's Bay I took thy captive ſloop.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There, egad! he comes out to be the very Captain of the privateer who had taken Whiſkerandos priſoner—and was himſelf an old lover of Tilburina's.

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Admirably manag'd indeed.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Now, ſtand out of their way.

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: I thank thee fortune! that haſt thus beſtow'd
A weapon to chaſtiſe this inſolent.

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: I take thy challenge, Spaniard, and I thank
Thee Fortune too!—

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: That's excellently contrived!—it ſeems as if the two uncles had left their ſwords on purpoſe for them.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No, egad, they could not help leaving them.

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: Vengeance and Tilburina!

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: Exactly ſo—
sp.stage: They fight—and after the uſual number of wounds given, Whiſkerandos falls.

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: O curſed parry!—that laſt thruſt in tierce
Was fatal—Captain, thou haſt fenced well!
And Whiſkerandos quits this buſtling ſcene
For all eter—

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: —nity—He would have added, but ſtern death
Cut ſhort his being, and the noun at once!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O, my dear Sir, you are too ſlow, now mind me.—Sir, ſhall I trouble you to die again?

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.l: And Whiſkerandos quits this buſtling ſcene
For all eter—

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: —nity—He would have added—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: No, Sir—that's not it—once more if you pleaſe—

sp.speaker: WHISKERANDOS.
sp.p: I wiſh, Sir—you would practiſe this without me—I can't ſtay dying here all night.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Very well, we'll go over it by and bye—I muſt humour theſe gentlemen!

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.l: Farewell—brave Spaniard! and when next—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Dear Sir, you needn't ſpeak that ſpeech as the body has walked off.

sp.speaker: BEEFEATER.
sp.p: That's true, Sir—then I'll join the fleet.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: If you pleaſe.
Now, who comes on?
sp.stage: Enter GOVERNOR, with his hair properly diſordered.

sp.speaker: GOVERNOR.
sp.l: A hemiſphere of evil planets reign!
And every planet ſheds contagious phrenſy!
My Spaniſh priſoner is ſlain! my daughter,
Meeting the dead corſe borne along—has gone
Diſtract!
But hark! I am ſummon'd to the fort,
Perhaps the fleets have met! amazing criſis!
O Tilburina! from thy aged father's beard
Thou'ſt pluck'd the few brown hairs which time had left!

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Poor gentleman!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes—and no one to blame but his daughter!

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: And the planets—

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: True.—Now enter Tilburina!—

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Egad, the buſineſs comes on quick here.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—now ſhe comes in ſtark mad in white ſatin.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Why in white ſatin?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir—when a heroine goes mad, ſhe always goes into white ſatin—don't ſhe, Dangle?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Always—it's a rule.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes—here it is— (looking at the book.) 'Enter Tilburina ſtark mad in white ſatin, and her confidant ſtark mad in white linen.'

div.stage: Enter TILBURINA and CONFIDANT mad, according to cuſtom.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But what the deuce, is the confidant to be mad too?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: To be ſure ſhe is, the confidant is always to do whatever her miſtreſs does; weep when ſhe weeps, ſmile when ſhe ſmiles, go mad when ſhe goes mad.—Now madam confidant—but —keep your madneſs in the back ground, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: TILBURINA.
sp.l: The wind whiſtles—the moon riſes—ſee
They have kill'd my ſquirrel in his cage!
Is this a graſshopper!—Ha! no, it is my
Whiſkerandos—you ſhall not keep him—
I know you have him in your pocket—
An oyſter may be croſs'd in love!—Who ſays
A whale's a bird?—Ha! did you call, my love?
—He's here! He's there!—He's every where!
Ah me! He's no where!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: There, do you ever deſire to ſee any body madder than that?

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: Never while I live!

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: You obſerved how ſhe mangled the metre?

sp.speaker: DANGLE.
sp.p: Yes—egad, it was the firſt thing made me ſuſpect ſhe was out of her ſenſes.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: And pray what becomes of her?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: She is gone to throw herſelf into the ſea to be ſure—and that brings us at once to the ſcene of action, and ſo to my cataſtrophe—my ſea-fight, I mean.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: What, you bring that in at laſt?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes—yes—you know my play is called the Spaniſh Armada, otherwiſe, egad, I have no occaſion for the battle at all.—Now then for my magnificence!—my battle!—my noiſe!—and my proceſſion!—You are all ready?

sp.speaker: PROMPTER within.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Is the Thames dreſt?

sp.speaker: THAMES.
sp.p: Here I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Very well indeed—See, gentlemen, there's a river for you!—This is blending a little of the maſque with my tragedy—a new fancy you know—and very uſeful in my caſe; for as there muſt be a proceſſion, I ſuppoſe Thames and all his tributary rivers to compliment Britannia with a fete in honor of the victory.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: But pray, who are theſe gentlemen in green with him.

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Thoſe?—thoſe are his banks.

sp.speaker: SNEER.
sp.p: His banks?

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Yes, one crown'd with alders and the other with a villa!—you take the alluſions?—but hey! what the plague! you have got both your banks on one ſide—Here Sir, come round—Ever while you live, Thames, go between your banks. (Bell rings.)—There, ſoh! now for't!—Stand aſide my dear friends!—away Thames!

div.stage: [Flouriſh of drums—trumpets—cannon, &c. &c. Scene changes to the ſea—the fleets engage—the muſick plays 'Britons ſtrike home.'—Spaniſh fleet deſtroyed by fire-ſhips, &c.—Engliſh fleet advances, —muſick plays 'Rule Britannia.'—The proceſſion of all the Engliſh rivers and their tributaries with their emblems, &c. begins with Handels water muſick—ends with a chorus, to the march in Judas Maccabaeus.—During this ſcene, Puff directs and applauds every thing—then]

sp.speaker: PUFF.
sp.p: Well, pretty well—but not quite perfect—ſo ladies and gentlemen, if you pleaſe, we'll rehearſe this piece again to-morrow.
